post.author: Seung Yeop Kim
post.content:
Using passprop.exe
By Mike Marney, searchSystemsManagement memeber

You can add properties to your passwords, as this tip, from reader
Mike Marney, points out.

Passprop.exe, a command-line tool from the Windows NT resource kit,
can be used to set two domain policy flags, whether passwords have to
be complex and whether the Administrator account can be locked out.
These domain password and security properties cannot be set by any
other tool, including the NET command and User Manager.

The first property is password complexity. If password complexity is
enabled, the password must be mixedcase (including a combination of
upper and lowercase letters) or contain numbers or symbols. If it is
not enabled, passwords are still case-sensitive but they are not
required to be mixedcase or contain numbers or symbols.

The second property is whether the Administrator user account can be
locked out. If locking out the Administrator user account is enabled,
then once it is locked out it can only be used to log on
interactively on domain controllers: network logons or logons to
non-domain controllers will fail.

passprop with no parameters

Displays domain policies for password complexity and Administrator
lockout.
For details on PASSPROP syntax and usage: at the command prompt,
type:

passprop /?

This is what will be displayed:
PASSPROP [/complex] [/simple] [/adminlockout] [/noadminlockout]

/complex -- Forces passwords to be complex, requiring passwords to be
a mix of upper and lowercase letters and numbers or symbols.
/simple -- Allows passwords to be simple.
/adminlockout -- Allows the Administrator account to be locked out.
The Administrator account can still log on interactively on domain
controllers.
/noadminlockout -- Allows the Administrator account not to be locked
out.
Additional properties can be set using User Manager or the NET
ACCOUNTS command.
post.title: Security Tip: Using passprop.exe
